clusters.neutral_headline: Canadian Olympic snowboarder turned alleged cocaine kingpin in US custody

items.title: Alleged drug kingpin and ex-Olympian Ryan Wedding arrested after years on the run
items.standfirst: Wedding, who had been on the FBI's Ten Most Wanted Fugitives list, is accused of running a transnational drug trafficking operation.
items.content: Wedding, who had been on the FBI's Ten Most Wanted Fugitives list, is accused of running a transnational drug trafficking operation.

items.title: A Canadian Olympic snowboarder turned alleged drug kingpin is arrested in Mexico
items.standfirst: Ryan Wedding was among the FBI's top fugitives and faces charges related to drug trafficking and the killing of a federal witness. He reportedly turned himself in at the U.S. embassy in Mexico
items.content: Ryan Wedding was among the FBI's top fugitives and faces charges related to drug trafficking and the killing of a federal witness. He reportedly turned himself in at the U.S. embassy in Mexico(Image credit: Damian Dovarganes)

items.title: Ryan Wedding, Olympic athlete turned alleged drug kingpin, arrested, officials say
items.standfirst: Ryan Wedding, a 44-year-old Canadian national, was added to the FBI's Ten Most Wanted Fugitives list last year.
items.content: Ryan Wedding, a 44-year-old Canadian national, was added to the FBI's Ten Most Wanted Fugitives list last year.

items.title: Canadian Olympic snowboarder turned alleged cocaine kingpin in US custody
items.standfirst: Ryan Wedding turned himself in at US consulate in Mexico City and is due to appear in court in California on MondayRyan Wedding, the Canadian Olympic snowboarder turned alleged drug kingpin, has been arrested after turning himself in at the US embassy in Mexico, law enforcement officials announced on Friday.Wedding, 44, had been sought by the FBI and the Royal Canadian Mounted Police (RCMP) for his role in overseeing what the US attorney general, Pam Bondi, called the “one of the most prolific and violent drug-trafficking organizations” in the world. Continue reading...
items.content: Ryan Wedding turned himself in at US consulate in Mexico City and is due to appear in court in California on MondayRyan Wedding, the Canadian Olympic snowboarder turned alleged drug kingpin, has been arrested after turning himself in at the US embassy in Mexico, law enforcement officials announced on Friday.Wedding, 44, had been sought by the FBI and the Royal Canadian Mounted Police (RCMP) for his role in overseeing what the US attorney general, Pam Bondi, called the “one of the most prolific and violent drug-trafficking organizations” in the world. Continue reading...

items.title: Olympic Snowboarder Turned "Cocaine Kingpin" Arrested In Mexico, Flown To US To Face Justice
items.standfirst: Olympic Snowboarder Turned "Cocaine Kingpin" Arrested In Mexico, Flown To US To Face Justice Former Olympic snowboarder Ryan Wedding, who was wanted by the FBI for allegedly leading a violent international drug trafficking operation, has been arrested, the Justice Department announced…
items.content: Olympic Snowboarder Turned "Cocaine Kingpin" Arrested In Mexico, Flown To US To Face Justice Former Olympic snowboarder Ryan Wedding, who was wanted by the FBI for allegedly leading a violent international drug trafficking operation, has been arrested, the Justice Department announced…

items.title: Ryan Wedding, Olympic snowboarder turned alleged drug kingpin, arrested, officials say
items.standfirst: Ryan Wedding, the former Olympic snowboarder who allegedly became a drug kingpin and is accused of orchestrating multiple murders, has been arrested, FBI Director Kash Patel announced on Friday. CBS News' Anna Shecter reports.
items.content: Ryan Wedding, the former Olympic snowboarder who allegedly became a drug kingpin and is accused of orchestrating multiple murders, has been arrested, FBI Director Kash Patel announced on Friday. CBS News' Anna Shecter reports.

clusters.title: Are Trump and Canada's Mark Carney feuding?
clusters.neutral_headline: Trump withdraws Canada's invitation to Board of Peace

items.title: Are Trump and Canada's Mark Carney feuding?
items.standfirst: President Trump says the invitation for Canada to join his "Board of Peace" has been withdrawn. CBS News' Olivia Rinaldi reports as Trump reacts to Canada's Mark Carney's comments on the U.S.
items.content: President Trump says the invitation for Canada to join his "Board of Peace" has been withdrawn. CBS News' Olivia Rinaldi reports as Trump reacts to Canada's Mark Carney's comments on the U.S.

items.title: Carney fires back at Trump after Davos speech
items.standfirst: "Canada doesn't live because of the United States. Canada thrives because we are Canadian," Canadian Prime Minister Mark Carney responded Thursday.
items.content: "Canada doesn't live because of the United States. Canada thrives because we are Canadian," Canadian Prime Minister Mark Carney responded Thursday.

items.title: Trump withdraws Canada's invite to his 'Board of Peace'
items.standfirst: President Donald Trump has withdrawn his invitation for his Canadian Prime Minister Mark Carney to join his "Board of Peace" after his Davos speech.
items.content: President Donald Trump has withdrawn his invitation for his Canadian Prime Minister Mark Carney to join his "Board of Peace" after his Davos speech.

items.title: Trump withdraws Canada's invitation to Board of Peace
items.standfirst: Trump did not provide a reason for the decision, which comes after Canada's PM Mark Carney warned of a "rupture" in the US-led global order.
items.content: Trump did not provide a reason for the decision, which comes after Canada's PM Mark Carney warned of a "rupture" in the US-led global order.

items.title: Trump withdraws invitation for Canada to join his global ‘board of peace’
items.standfirst: While leaders of many liberal democracies declined to sign on, Mark Carney had, before Davos, accepted in principleDonald Trump withdrew on Thursday an invitation for Canada to join his “board of peace” initiative aimed at resolving global conflicts.“Please let this Letter serve to represent that the Board of Peace is withdrawing its invitation to you regarding Canada’s joining, what will be, the most prestigious Board of Leaders ever assembled, at any time,” Trump wrote in a Truth Social post directed at the Canadian prime minister, Mark Carney. Continue reading...
items.content: While leaders of many liberal democracies declined to sign on, Mark Carney had, before Davos, accepted in principleDonald Trump withdrew on Thursday an invitation for Canada to join his “board of peace” initiative aimed at resolving global conflicts.“Please let this Letter serve to represent that the Board of Peace is withdrawing its invitation to you regarding Canada’s joining, what will be, the most prestigious Board of Leaders ever assembled, at any time,” Trump wrote in a Truth Social post directed at the Canadian prime minister, Mark Carney. Continue reading...

clusters.title: Starmer rebukes Trump over ‘frankly appalling’ remarks on Nato troops in Afghanistan
clusters.neutral_headline: Starmer condemns Trump’s ‘appalling’ claim that Nato avoided Afghan frontline

items.title: Starmer rebukes Trump over ‘frankly appalling’ remarks on Nato troops in Afghanistan
items.standfirst: PM joins veterans in condemning claim that troops avoided frontlines and suggests US president should apologiseKeir Starmer has issued an unprecedented rebuke to Donald Trump for his “insulting and frankly appalling” remarks about British and other Nato troops in Afghanistan, and suggested he should apologise.After a day of mounting outrage around the world over the US president’s claim that British and Nato troops who fought in Afghanistan avoided the frontlines, Starmer paid tribute to the 457 members of the armed services who lost their lives during the conflict. Continue reading...
items.content: PM joins veterans in condemning claim that troops avoided frontlines and suggests US president should apologiseKeir Starmer has issued an unprecedented rebuke to Donald Trump for his “insulting and frankly appalling” remarks about British and other Nato troops in Afghanistan, and suggested he should apologise.After a day of mounting outrage around the world over the US president’s claim that British and Nato troops who fought in Afghanistan avoided the frontlines, Starmer paid tribute to the 457 members of the armed services who lost their lives during the conflict. Continue reading...

items.title: Starmer condemns Trump’s ‘appalling’ claim that Nato avoided Afghan frontline
items.standfirst: UK prime minister says US president should apologise for comments in latest sign of strain between allies
items.content: UK prime minister says US president should apologise for comments in latest sign of strain between allies

items.title: 'Insulting and frankly appalling': PM condemns Trump's remarks on UK troops in Afghanistan
items.standfirst: Sir Keir Starmer has said Donald Trump's claims British troops were not on the frontline in Afghanistan were "insulting and frankly appalling" - and suggested he should apologise.
items.content: Sir Keir Starmer has said Donald Trump's claims British troops were not on the frontline in Afghanistan were "insulting and frankly appalling" - and suggested he should apologise.

items.title: Starmer slams Trump’s 'appalling' claims that NATO troops avoided front lines in Afghanistan
items.standfirst: The UK on Thursday said Donald Trump was "wrong to diminish" NATO's role in Afghanistan after the US president suggested allied troops were not on the front lines, sparking outrage in the country and among families of the hundreds of British soldiers killed in the war. Prime Minister Keir Starmer slammed Trump's comments as "insulting" and "appalling".
items.content: The UK on Thursday said Donald Trump was "wrong to diminish" NATO's role in Afghanistan after the US president suggested allied troops were not on the front lines, sparking outrage in the country and among families of the hundreds of British soldiers killed in the war. Prime Minister Keir Starmer slammed Trump's comments as "insulting" and "appalling".

items.title: Could trilateral talks yield a breakthrough in Ukraine-Russia war?

items.content: Trump administration officials are denying accounts from witnesses who say they saw what occurred during a Minnesota ICE raid where a 5-year-old boy and his father were detained.

items.title: BREAKING: Immigration officials address detained 5-year-old boy in Minnesota
items.standfirst: ICE Executive Assistant Director Marco Charles and Border Patrol Commander at Large Greg Bovino spoke out today about the ...
items.content: ICE Executive Assistant Director Marco Charles and Border Patrol Commander at Large Greg Bovino spoke out today about the ...

items.title: Minnesota: Five-year old boy detained by ICE
items.standfirst: US Immigration and Enforcement (ICE) officers this week detained five-year-old Liam Conejo Ramos in Minnesota as he was returning home from preschool, with school officials and witnesses saying agents used the child to lure out and arrest his father. The witnesses also said that the agents refused to leave him in the care of another adult, "essentially using him as bait”.
items.content: US Immigration and Enforcement (ICE) officers this week detained five-year-old Liam Conejo Ramos in Minnesota as he was returning home from preschool, with school officials and witnesses saying agents used the child to lure out and arrest his father. The witnesses also said that the agents refused to leave him in the care of another adult, "essentially using him as bait”.

items.title: Minnesotans strike to protest ICE surge in state: ‘No work, no school, no shopping’
items.standfirst: Organizers demand ICE leave state and agency be investigated for constitutional violationsICE protests – live updatesA “no work, no school, no shopping” blackout day of protest was kicked off by community leaders, faith leaders and labor unions on Friday in protest against the Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) surge in the state.The “Day of Truth & Freedom” protest comes in the wake of the killing of Renee Good, the unarmed woman killed by a federal immigration officer in Minneapolis earlier this month. Continue reading...
items.content: Organizers demand ICE leave state and agency be investigated for constitutional violationsICE protests – live updatesA “no work, no school, no shopping” blackout day of protest was kicked off by community leaders, faith leaders and labor unions on Friday in protest against the Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) surge in the state.The “Day of Truth & Freedom” protest comes in the wake of the killing of Renee Good, the unarmed woman killed by a federal immigration officer in Minneapolis earlier this month. items.standfirst: Much-anticipated trial scheduled in New York over killing of United Healthcare CEO Brian ThompsonLuigi Mangione’s federal murder trial in the killing of the United HealthCare CEO Brian Thompson is scheduled to start with jury selection on 8 September, triggering one of the most eagerly anticipated criminal trials in recent US history, a judge said on Friday.Judge Margaret Garnett of announced the trial date to a packed Manhattan federal courtroom shortly before an evidence-related hearing in his case. Continue reading...

clusters.neutral_headline: Trump says US ‘armada’ heading to Middle East as Iran death toll put above 5,000

items.title: Trump warns U.S. 'armada' heading to Iran; death toll in protest crackdown tops 5,000, activists say
items.standfirst: President Donald Trump said an American "armada" is heading toward Iran, as the death toll from the regime's crackdown on nationwide unrest rose past at least 5,000, activists said
items.content: President Donald Trump said an American "armada" is heading toward Iran, as the death toll from the regime's crackdown on nationwide unrest rose past at least 5,000, activists said

items.title: Trump says US ‘armada’ heading to Middle East as Iran death toll put above 5,000
items.standfirst: US president says ‘we have a lot of ships’ going in that direction and that Washington is watching Iran closelyDonald Trump has said an American “armada” is heading towards the Middle East and that the US is monitoring Iran closely, as activists put the death toll from Tehran’s crackdown on protesters at 5,002.Speaking on Air Force One as he returned from the World Economic Forum in Davos overnight, he said: “We have a lot of ships going that direction, just in case. I’d rather not see anything happen, but we’re watching them very closely … we have an armada … heading in that direction, and maybe we won’t have to use it.” Continue reading...
items.content: US president says ‘we have a lot of ships’ going in that direction and that Washington is watching Iran closelyDonald Trump has said an American “armada” is heading towards the Middle East and that the US is monitoring Iran closely, as activists put the death toll from Tehran’s crackdown on protesters at 5,002.Speaking on Air Force One as he returned from the World Economic Forum in Davos overnight, he said: “We have a lot of ships going that direction, just in case. I’d rather not see anything happen, but we’re watching them very closely … we have an armada … heading in that direction, and maybe we won’t have to use it.” Continue reading...

items.title: Trump warns massive ‘armada’ heading toward Iran
items.standfirst: President Trump told reporters that a massive “armada” is heading toward Iran as the country cracks down on nationwide protests. Mass executions and the killing of peaceful protests have been two red lines laid down by Trump in the tensions.
items.content: President Trump told reporters that a massive “armada” is heading toward Iran as the country cracks down on nationwide protests. Mass executions and the killing of peaceful protests have been two red lines laid down by Trump in the tensions.
